Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Who is (Not) Complying with the Social Distancing Directive and Why?

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
In the current COVID-19 pandemic, one approach to minimizing the spread of the virus focuses on people’s behavior – social distancing. Since the start of the pandemic, government leaders and health experts have requested citizens to follow social distancing directives. Despite this repeated message and despite the fact that many people are taking the message seriously, many others are violating the new norms. That raises important questions: who is and who is not complying, and why? Understanding why people choose not to practice social distancing is crucial for designing effective public service campaigns. This research investigates who complies, what specific beliefs should be addressed, and what factors make public campaigns believable. The project seeks to identify the factors that lead to greater compliance for the greater good, and will inform future public service campaigns.

A series of studies examines how social distancing behaviors vary as a function of belief systems. An innovative measure of social distancing is developed – one that is more behavioral in nature than the typical survey. The critical beliefs that are to be examined stem from a conceptual framework regarding a directive as involving three essential components. One is the source -- someone is requesting people to change their behavior. A second is the surrounding context -- the request is in response to some challenge. The third component is the target -- the persons to whom the request is addressed. Belief systems relevant to each of these three components are expected to influence the likelihood that people will comply with the request. As a result, an entire network of beliefs is expected to influence how people respond and why. Some individuals’ belief systems will lead them to view the request favorably, thus promoting appropriate social distancing behaviors. Others will reach more negative conclusions and subsequently refuse to take directives seriously. Once the concerns about the pandemic have lessened, study participants will be re-contacted and asked to again respond to social distancing behavioral scenarios and to indicate if they had experienced virus symptoms in the interim. Those follow-up data will shed light on the relationship between individuals’ social distancing behaviors and their subsequent likelihood of infection. The research aims to inform theory regarding social compliance processes, and will provide a stronger foundation for developing future public service campaigns.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Overview: The research involved a series of studies concerning compliance with the directive to engage in social distancing in the interest of containing the spread of the COVID-19 virus. The research examined the relation between relevant belief systems and social distancing behavior, as well as the extent to which such behavior is predictive of subsequent illness. The novel aspect of the research was its focus on an innovative, behaviorally-oriented approach to the measurement of social distancing, one that went beyond asking participants to report on the frequency with which they have engaged in social distancing. Instead, our virtual behavior measures presented participants with graphical images of different scenarios and asked them to position themselves in relation to others in the scene. For example, one item presented people with a street scene and asked them to choose whether to follow a path that passed directly in front of another individual or to detour via the crosswalk. The belief systems that were examined as predictors of these social distancing behaviors included beliefs about the source of the directive (faith in government, trust in science), its surrounding context (perceptions of COVID-19 as a serious threat, accurate knowledge regarding the coronavirus), and the individual?s own propensities (e.g., perceived vulnerability to disease, interpersonal compassion, belief in generic conspiracy theories). Each of these variables related substantially to the virtual measure of social distancing behavior.  Moreover, longitudinal data revealed that individuals' social distancing behavior predicted whether they contracted COVID-19 during the intervening four months. 

Intellectual Merit: Theory and research concerning compliance (behavioral change in response to an explicit or implicit request) has been central to social psychology for decades. Despite having acquired substantial knowledge regarding social influence tactics that can promote compliance, the field lacks a general theoretical framework about who is likely to comply with a directive, and why they might or might not do so. Such a framework is particularly important when considering a directive calling for compliance and behavior change on a large scale, as was true of the COVID-19 pandemic and the directive to engage in social distancing. The research addressed this gap in our knowledge by testing a theory regarding the who and why of compliance. The theory begins with the assertion that any directive necessarily will be viewed through the lens of the individual?s knowledge, beliefs, and attitudes, all of which will influence the individual?s assessment of the directive as worthy of compliance or not. The theoretical framework centers upon three essential components of any directive: (1) the source, some entity is advocating for a behavioral change; (2) the surrounding context, the directive is in response to some challenge; and (3) the target, the persons to whom the directive is addressed? Belief systems relevant to each of these three components influence the likelihood of compliance. Is the source to be trusted? What does the surrounding context imply about the seriousness of the challenge? As for the targets, are there individual propensities (self-characteristics) that affect responsivity to the directive. The findings offered clear support for this framework in the context of the pandemic. Source and target variables related strongly to evaluations of the threat posed by COVID-19 and to acquired knowledge about the virus. These variables related to the extent of social distancing that individuals exhibited on the virtual measure, and virtual distancing behavior predicted the likelihood of testing positively for COVID-19 during the subsequent four months.

Broader Impacts: Given the focus on the COVID-19 pandemic, the project was directly relevant to the public health crisis and to any similar future crises. The findings provided a wealth of information about whom public health campaigns should target to encourage social distancing and, more importantly, the beliefs that should be targeted in such efforts. They especially highlighted the importance of individuals? development of accurate knowledge about COVID-19 and the importance of consistent, non-contradictory messages from the various relevant sources (government officials and scientists). Moreover, the longitudinal data demonstrating the relation between individual social distancing behaviors and reports of subsequent illness should be of significant value in convincing skeptics of the value of social distancing. It is not only the community that benefits from compliance with the social distancing directive, but also the very individual engaged in the recommended behavior.
